Gentlemen Prefer Blondes: The Women of Le Bonheur and Cleo From 5 to 7

25/08/2022

Cavan looks at how women are presented in the work of Agnes Varda

Image by IMDb

By Lawrence Mason

Agnes Varda was a majestic filmmaker, always at the forefront of French cinema with a style that could only be described as having films that spoke. Her films, in their deeply profound style, held conversations with the audience about their identity, their gender, their morality, ethics and even the audience's own happiness. You can see this in her documentary short Black Panthers, where all of the dialogue comes from interviews with the activists, providing the oppressed with a direct voice that was loud, proud and ready to celebrate its mere existence as well as its political progress. Equally Ydessa, the Bears and etc. lets a fellow artist express their voice in their own way, showing their art as a way of laying a fundamental part of their soul out for all to engage with. In a nutshell, Varda amplified the voices of those who needed to be heard, and both Le Bonheur and Cleo From 5 to 7 gave Vardaâ€™s feminist mode a chance to elevate the voices of women.

Both works present a similar selection of female characters; objectified for their beauty, hovered over constantly by men and defined by sexual attraction to and from men. However, there is something much deeper to the way women are presented in this thematic duology, and that is the question of agency in the face of objectification.

Varda once said â€˜happiness is a beautiful fruit that tastes of crueltyâ€™, and in Le Bonheur female attraction is shown as thus. Francois is a man trapped between two sources of happiness; his loving wife and children, and the post office operative he is having an affair with. Both adore him, his wife is frequently told about his happiness with their marriage and thus is tricked into seeing him as the ideal husband; something his infidelity would dispute. Therese, Francoisâ€™ wife, doesnâ€™t question him much throughout the film, and embodies the traditional image of the wife down to a tee; sheâ€™s slavishly doting on her husband and children and even encourages (and enjoys) sex. She is subservient to her husband's whims, objectifying her to the point where Francois merely uses her for escapism from the existential crisis brought on by his affair. When Therese is implied to have drowned herself, her real value to Francois is revealed; as it turns out, there wasnâ€™t any. Francois immediately finds happiness with Ã‰milie, the post office worker, whom he has now married. Varda makes the choice to cast near identical women as Therese and Ã‰milie, which serves as a damning statement about the role of women in menâ€™s happiness.

She shows that, ultimately, patriarchal society sees women as playthings, toys for men to play with until they find something that offers them the same thrills. A final state of objectification where even in death they are forgotten for the â€˜better modelâ€™. Francoisâ€™ internal ethical and moral crisis is played off as wholly sarcastic, a farce where he artificially engineers his own misery when we exclusively see him happy. When his wife dies, itâ€™s difficult to take what little sadness we see in him seriously as Varda poses that â€˜she canâ€™t have meant that much to him, could she?â€™ There is a hidden message about the cycles of patriarchy running deep within Le Bonheur, a cycle where there are no repercussions for male misdemeanours; which, let's be honest, is no different from the society of today. Francois occupies a world where no justice shall reach his wife, she shall never see her husband fall, since his happiness dictates the value of the objectified female characters of the film. Both women in Le Bonheur occupy shallow existences where their value is determined by how happy they make Francois, without any considerations taken towards their own happiness.

Cleo From 5 to 7 touches on many of the same themes as Le Bonheur, those of women being given value through male observation and acknowledgement. However, Cleo focuses more on womenâ€™s sadness or madness being defined by male interference. The women of Le Bonheur have their happiness determined by how happy Francois is with them, whereas Cleo has her emotions valued and judged by men who deem her troublesome because she believes she will die. She is forbidden from contemplating her own existence and mortality, men see this as something damaging to their shallow ideals of happiness so they try to silence maudlin discussions of death, telling her sheâ€™s faking fear for attention. The problem for the men here is that she is gaining the wrong type of attention, Cleo is asking for help but the male gaze desires only sexual gratification and power. They cannot easily objectify a person asking for help but they are able to objectify someone seeking sexual attention, the â€œrightâ€ attention which gives Cleo value in their eyes.

At one point in the film Cleo utters the line â€˜as long as Iâ€™m beautiful, Iâ€™m aliveâ€™, and Varda lays out bluntly what men want from Cleo and women as a whole; silence, and something nice to stare at. Without beauty, women have no voice in Cleoâ€™s world, they silently cry out for help from men who simply canâ€™t be bothered to acknowledge the moral crisis of the opposite sex. It is interesting that the only male character in Cleo From 5 to 7 that is in any way sympathetic to Cleoâ€™s existential crisis is a French soldier reeling from the horrors of war in Algeria, where men like him are sent to die for no purpose. Varda compares the two cases interestingly; a woman objectified for her beauty and a man for his bravery, yet neither see themselves as those things. They see themselves beyond simple objective descriptions, they see themselves as three dimensional humans who need help.

Vardaâ€™s pair of films show us the silence which women endure within patriarchal objectification, a world where their own emotions have to be determined by their perceived value to the men they meet. These are important films for many reasons, but they are vital at showing us the existential threat that comes with womanhood.
